THE OLD QUARRY ASSOCIATION INC., , GUILFORD, CT
ZONING ORDINANCE OF 1991
SECTION 1 - Statement of Purpose
1.1
It is the purpose of these Regulations to promote the health,
safety, and general welfare of the community; to encourage the
most appropriate use of the land with respect to the unique
character of the natural terrain; to lessen congestion in the
public ways; to avoid undue concentration of the population;
to make adequate provision for public utilities and facilities;
to provide adequate light, air, and recreational facilities;
to secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; and to
conserve property values in The Old Quarry Association by
preserving the characteristics of a park-like residential
community where privacy, views and harmony of design are of
concern.
1.2
Nothing in this Ordinance is intended to abrogate or repeal the
provisions of any other ordinance or regulation, except as
hereinafter specified, or to affect or modify in any way the
conditions or restrictions in any convenant or deed or order
issued in pursuance thereof, and where the provisions of this
ordinance differ from any such other restrictions or regulations
the more restrictive shall prevail.

-2-
SECTION 2 - Definitions
2.1
The words used in these Regulations shall have the meaning
commonly attributed to them. Doubts as to their precise
meaning, application or interpretation shall be determined
by the Commission In accordance with the purpose and intent of
these Regulations.
2.2
On appeal from a decision of the Zoning Commission or its
duly appointed Zoning Enforcement Agent as to the meaning of any
word or words used herein, the Board of Appeals shall interpret
and determine the intent thereof and adopt a rule explicitly
setting forth such interpretation.
2.3
Architectural Presentations: Drawings and specifications, when
required by these Regulations, shall be prepared by a registered
architect or registered engineer, except for minor additions or
modifications as described in paragraph 5.8.1 (b).
2.4
Attic: The space between the ceiling beams of the top story and
the roof rafters.
2.5
Basement: A story of a building, partly below the finished
grade level, which has more than one-half (1/2) of its height,
measured from floor to ceiling, above the average established
finished grade of the land immediately adjacent to the building.

-3-
2.6
Building: A structure which is completely enclosed by a roof
and by solid exterior walls along whose outside faces can be
traced an unbroken line for the complete circumference of the
structure, and which is permanently affixed to a lot or lots
and used or intended for the shelter, support, or enclosure of
persons, animals, or property of any kind.
2.7
Building, Accessory: A building located on the same lot as a
principal building and devoted or intended to be devoted to an
accessory use. Any portion of a principal building devoted or
intended to be devoted to an accessory use is not an accessory
building.
2.8
Building Area: The total of areas taken on a horizontal plane
at the mean grade level of the principal buildings and all
accessory buildings, exclusive of decks, terraces and steps.
Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall
be included in the building area if such areas are included
within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above.
2.9
Building, Principal: A building in which is conducted, or is
intended to be conducted, the principal use of the lot on which
it is located.

-4-

Dwelling Unit: Any room or group of rooms located within a
building devoted to residential use and forming a single
habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be

Family: One person, persons related by blood, marriage or
adoption, or a group of not more than four persons not so related
who are living together as a single housekeeping unit maintaining
a common household.

-5-
2.17
Floor Area: The sum of the gross horizontal areas of the
several stories of a building or other structure measured
from the exterior faces of the exterior walls, excluding
terraces, crawl spaces, decks, and other horizontal areas not
accessible by a permanent inside stairway.
2.18
Floor Area Ratio: The floor area in square feet of all
buildings on a lot divided by the area of such lot in square
feet.
2.19
Height of building or other structure shall be measured
from the lowest natural ground level against the building
to the maximum height of any part of the structure.
"Natural ground level" is defined as the existing ground level
prior to any site preparation, grading, or filling of the lot.
2.20
Lot: A parcel of land containing not less than 40,000 square
feet and being part of the premises shown on a map entitled
"OLD QUARRY-GUILFORD-CONNECTICUT. Scale - 1 inch = 100 feet.
July - 1946" prepared by Frederick C. Hahn, Civil Engineer and
Surveyor.
2.21
Lot Coverage: That percentage of the lot area covered by the
building area.

-6-
-
2.22
Non-Conforming - Building: A building which does not conform to
all of the applicable provisions of these regulations.
2.23
Project Design: Overall concept of elements on the site
including architectural design, site planning, site lighting,
and landscaping including trees to be added or removed.
2.24
Setbacks: The distance that buildings and/or other structures
are set back from front, rear, or side property lines as
required by these Regulations.
2.25 Story: That part of any building, exclusive of cellars and
crawl spaces and aréas enclosed by "breakaway walls" as
required by Flood Plain Regulations, but inclusive of basements,
comprised between the level of one finished floor and the level
of the next higher finished floor or if there is no higher
finished floor, then that part of the building comprised between
the level of the highest finished floor and the top of the roof
beams.
2.26
Story, Half: Any space, with a minimum clear height of five
(5) feet, partially within the roof framing where the clear
height of not more than fifty percent (50%) of such space
between the top of the floor beams and the structural ceiling
level is (7) feet six (6) inches or more.

-7-
2.27 Structure: Anything constructed or erected, including a
building, which has a permanent location on a lot or lots,
or anything attached to something having a permanent location
on the ground.

SECTION 3 - Jurisdiction
-8-
3.1
Section 8 of Special Act #306 of 1947 as amended by Section 2
of Special Act #43 of 1971, reads as follows:
Except as herein prescribed, the provisions of Chapter 124 of
the general statutes, as amended, shall be applicable to and
within The Old Quarry Association, and the zoning commission of
said association is herein designated to have exclusive
jurisdiction to function with respect to zoning within its
territorial limits, as shown on the map entitled "Old Quarry,
Guilford, Connecticut," scale 1 inch = 100 feet, July 1946,
prepared by Frederick C. Hahn, Civil Engineer and Surveyor.
The executive board of said association shall be its zoning
commission. Said executive board shall, at its first regular
meeting in each year, appoint a board of appeals consisting of
three persons eligible to hold office in said association.
In the event of a vacancy in the membership of said board of
appeals, said executive board may fill the same by appointment
for the unexpired portion of the term so vacant. Said zoning
commission and said board of appeals shall have the authority
conferred upon zoning commissions and boards of appeal in the
towns of the state.
3.2
Within the Old Quarry Association, no land, building or
other structure shall be used, and no building or other
structure shall be constructed, reconstructed, enlarged,
extended, moved or structurally altered, except in
conformity with these Regulations.

-9-
SECTION 4 - Permitted Uses
4.1
Land, buildings and other structures may be used for the
following purposes and no other:
4.1.1 A single-family detached dwelling for year-round use,
subject to the securing of a Permit from the Commission
in accordance with these Regulations.
4.1.2 An accessory building or structure, subject to the
securing of a Permit from the Commission in accordance
with these Regulations.
4.1.3 Offstreet parking for at least two registered vehicles
shall be provided for each principal dwelling unit.
4.1.4 All commercial motor vehicles and trucks, mobile homes,
campers, house trailers, and similar recreational
vehicles must be garaged in an enclosed structure and
shall not be occupied temporarily or otherwise.
4.1.5 No signs of any kind shall be permitted except:
(1) Directional signs approved by the Zoning Commission.
(2) A sign not exceeding 2 square feet in area giving
the name of the residential occupant.
(3) Special purpose signs only by permission of the
Executive Board.

-10-
4.2
Additions and alterations may be made to existing single-
family detached dwellings, subject to the securing of a
Permit from the Commission in accordance with these
Regulations.
4.3
Excavation or removal, or fill of any earth, loam, topsoil,
sand, gravel, clay or stone shall be subject to the securing of
a permit from the Commission in accordance with these
regulations except as follows:
4.3.1 Excavation or removal or fill reasonably necessary in
connection with the bona fide construction or alteration
of a building or other structure for which a Permit has
been issued by the Commission in accordance with these
Regulations.
4.3.2 Bona fide landscaping or beach maintenance operations on
a lot, provided that no more than 25 cubic yards of
material are added or removed in connection therewith.

-11-
4.4
Area, Bulk and Location Requirements:
Setback requirements from property lines of
adjacent lots shall be increased one foot for
each foot of building height over 10 feet.
Under this requirement lower parts of buildings
may be nearer to the basic setback line and
higher parts shall be further away.

SECTION 5 - Permits
5.1
Application for a Permit shall be submitted in writing to the
Commission, describing (briefly) the proposed use of the
building, structure, addition, or alteration; or the purpose
of the proposed excavation or removal, or fill, and accompanied
by the following:
5.1.1 A tracing or drawing showing the boundaries and
existing and proposed contours of the lot,
the location of all existing buildings, structures,
sewage disposal facilities, water supply facilities
and other utilities, and the location of all proposed
buildings, structures, sewage disposal facilities,
water supply facilities and other utilities or, in the
case of an application for a Permit under Paragraph 4.3,
a description of the location and quantity of the
proposed excavation or removal, or fill and location of
trees. Location of high tide line (CGS Section 22a-359).
5.1.2 Preliminary architectural plans of all proposed buildings
and structures, showing exterior elevations and exterior
materials and colors. The height, dimensions, use, total
floor area, number of stories, and location of all
buildings and other structures on the lot, whether
existing or proposed, with respect to all lot lines.

-13-
5.1.3 Such additional information as the Commission
may deem necessary in order to reach a decision
on the application.
5.1.4 The Commission may waive any item required under
Paragraphs 5.1.1 or 5.1.2 if it deems such
information unnecessary to its consideration of
the application.
5.1.5 A site visit should be arranged with a member of
the Commission after the house site has been staked
at all corners and a marker pole showing the most
visible part of the roof ridge has been installed.
5.2
The Commission may hold a public hearing on the application,
notice of which shall be given by mail not less that ten (10)
days before the hearing, to each member of the old Quarry
Association.
5.3
The Commission shall approve the application if it shall find
that the proposed use and the proposed buildings, structure,
addition or alteration or excavation or removal, or fill will
conform to these Regulations and the following standards:

- -14-
5.3.1 The location, type, character and size of the
proposed building, structure, addition or
alteration, or excavation, or removal or fill
shall be in harmony with and conform to the
appropriate and orderly development of The
Old Quarry Association and will not hinder or
discourage the appropriate development and use
of adjacent lots or impair the value thereof;
5.3.2 The nature and location of the proposed building,
structure, addition or alteration shall be such
that there will be adequate access to it for
fire protection purposes;
5.3.3 Provision is made for entering and leaving the lot
in such a manner that no undue traffic hazard or
congestion will be created;
5.3.4 The lot is of sufficient size and dimensions
to permit construction and maintenance of the
proposed building, structure, addition or
alteration, and facilities, including sanitary
facilities, in a manner that will not be detrimental
to adjacent lots;

-15-
5.3.5 The project design of the proposed buildings,
structure, addition or alteration shall be such
as not to conflict with the design of adjacent
properties. In determining whether there is a
conflict, the Commission may consider the location
of the building on the site, the height, floor area,
roof configuration and architectural style of the
building, the effect on views from adjacent
properties and the possible effect on the value of
other properties in the Association.
5.3.6 Lighting: The location, height, design, direction
and brightness of outdoor illumination (area lighting
and floodlighting) shall be arranged and maintained
as follows: To minimize sky glow, to harmonize with
the neighborhood, and to avoid glare on any other lot.
5.4
Site Work
5.4.1 No clearing or grading shall be undertaken until a
Permit has been issued.
5.4.2 No blasting shall be allowed without Special Permit.

-16-
5.4.3 No new sharp declivities, pits or depressions shall be
allowed. Proper drainage must be provided to avoid
stagnant water, soil erosion and water pollution.
After excavation, removal, or deposit of material, the
lot must be cleared of debris in such a way that the.
integrity of setback areas and of adjoining properties
is protected and visual quality is not impaired.
5.5
In granting a Permit, the Commission shall have the power to
impose such additional conditions and safeguards as it deems
necessary to carry out the purposes of these regulations.
5.6
No building construction, alteration or addition may be
commenced without obtaining required Building Permit therefor
from the Town of Guilford.
5.7
In special Flood Hazard Areas as defined in the "Flood Plain
Management Ordinance" of the Town of Guilford, the Permit shall
be issued only after any required Flood Hazard Area Permit has
been issued under such Ordinance.
5.8
Coastal Site Plan Review
Within the Association area, the Zoning Commission shall
exercise coastal site plan review, pursuant to the
provisions of the Coastal Management Act (Sections 22a-90
to 22a-112 of the Connecticut General Statutes.)

-17-
5.8.1 Applicability: All buildings, uses, and structures fully
or partially within the coastal boundary as defined by
Section 22a-94 of the Connecticut General Statutes and as
delineated on the Coastal Boundary Map for the Town of
Guilford shall be subject to the Coastal Site plan
review requirements and procedures in Sections 22a-105
through 22a-109 of the Connecticut General Statutes.
Pursuant to Section 22a-109 (b) of the Connecticut
General Statutes, the following activities are exempt
from Coastal Site Plan review requirements:
a. Gardening, grazing, and harvesting of crops.
b. Minor additions to or modifications of existing
buildings or detached accessory buildings, such as
garages and utility sheds. Minor additions mean an
addition not exceeding 20 percent of the first floor
area or 1,000 square feet, which ever is less.
C. Construction of new or modification of existing
structures incidental to the enjoyment and
maintenance of residential property including,
but not limited to: walks, terraces, driveways
swimming pools, tennis courts, docks, and
detached accessory buildings.

-18-
d. Construction of new or modification of existing on-
premise fences, walls, pedestrian walks and terraces,
underground utility connections, essential electric,
gas, telephone, water, and sewer service lines,
signs, and such other minor structures as will not
substantially alter the natural character of coastal
resources as defined by Section 22a-93 (7) of the
Connecticut General Statutes or restrict access along
the public beach.
e. Construction of a new single-family dwelling,
but only when such dwelling is not located
in or within 100 feet of the following coastal
resources as defined in Section 22a-93 (7) of the
Connecticut General Statutes: tidal wetlands,
coastal bluffs and escarpments, and beaches and
dunes.
f. Activities conducted for the specific purpose
of conserving or preserving soil, vegetation,
water, fish, shellfish, wildlife, and other
coastal land and water resources.
g. Interior modifications to buildings.

-19-
h. Minor changes in use of a building, structure, or
property, except those changes occurring on property
adjacent to or abutting coastal waters, or the change
from a water-dependent to a non-water dependent use.
5.8.2 In accordance with the provisions of Section 22a-105 (b)
and Section 22a-109 (b) of the Connecticut General
Statutes, the foregoing exemptions from coastal site
plan review requirements are applicable to buildings,
uses, and structures meeting the exemption criteria and
authorized under any of the following procedures:
a. Approval of a site plan under Section 5.1 of these
Regulations;
b. Grant of a variance from these Regulations by the
Zoning Board of Appeals under subdivision (3) of
Section 8-6 of the Statutes; and
C. The zoning commission may, at its discretion,
hold a hearing on a coastal site plan required
by this section. The commission shall hold a
hearing on a coastal site plan for a shoreline
flood and erosion control structure upon the
request of the commissioner of environmental
protection.

- -20- -
SECTION 6 - Non-Conformities
6.1
Non-Conformities, General: It is the intent of these Regula-
tions that non-conformities are not to be expanded,
and that the existence of any present non-conformity anywhere in
the Association shall not in itself be considered grounds for
the issuance of a variance for any other use, lot, building, or
other structure. Nothing in these Regulations shall be deemed
to prohibit ordinary repair and maintenance of any
non-conforming building or other structure or reconstruction
thereof necessitated by fire or other casualty, or replacement
of existing materials, or work ordered by the Building
Inspector, Fire Marshal, or Director of Health to protect the
public health or safety, provided such work does not increase
the non-conformity.
6.2
Non-Conforming Buildings and Structures: A non-conforming
building, or other structure which contains a permitted use
in the Old Quarry may be continued in accordance with the
following provisions and limitations:
6.2.1 No non-conforming building or other structure shall
be enlarged, extended, constructed, reconstructed, or
altered, if the result would be an increase in or an
extension of the non-conformity;

- -21- -
6.2.2 No non-conforming building or other structure shall
be moved unless the result of such moving is to
reduce or eliminate its non-conformity;
6.2.3 No non-conforming building or other structure,
1f once changed to conform or to more nearly
conform to these Regulations, shall thereafter
be changed so as to be less conforming;
6.2.4 These Regulations shall not prohibit reconstruction
of any building or structure where the building or
structure has been substantially damaged or
destroyed by any means out of control of the owner,
provided the reconstruction shall in no way increase
any former non-conformity and provided further that
reconstruction is begun within one (1) year of such
substantial damage or destruction and diligently
pursued to completion within two (2) years following
such substantial damage or destruction.
SECTION 7 - Enforcement and Administration
7.1
This ordinance shall be enforced by the Zoning Commission
or its duly appointed Zoning Enforcement Agent, the Clerk
of the Old Quarry Association.

-22-
7.2
No building or other structure shall be erected, moved,
enlarged, or structurally altered nor shall the use of any
premises or part thereof be changed until a Building Permit
therefor has been issued by the Zoning Commission.
7.3
If no work has been commenced upon the subject matter of a
Building Permit within six (6) months from the date of issuance,
such Building Permit shall expire by limitation. In the case
of new structures, work commenced shall mean commencement
of fabrication above ground level. All work described in
such Building Permit shall be finished and a Certificate of
Occupancy applied for within eighteen (18) months from the
issuance date of the Permit. Provided, however, that the
Zoning Commission may extend the time for completion by an
additional twelve (12) months on written application made
prior to expiration of such 18-month period.
7.4
No building or premises or part thereof hereafter created,
erected, enlarged, moved, converted or altered, wholly or
partly, or the open spaces of which are reduced, shall be
occupied or used until a Certificate of Occupancy has been
issued by the Zoning Commission or its duly appointed
Zoning Enforcement Agent showing that the building or
premises, or part thereof, and the proposed use are in
conformity with the provisions of this ordinance.

-23-
Such certificate shall be issued, or refused for reasons
stated in writing, within one (1) week of the application
therefor.
7.5
The zoning enforcement officer is authorized to issue a
stop Order if in his or her judgment the use of any land,
building of other structure, or the construction, re-
construction, enlargement, extension, moving or structural
alteration of a building or other structure, is not being
carried out in compliance with these Regulations. He or she
shall withdraw such Stop Order when he or she determines
that corrective action has been taken to comply with these
Regulations.
7.6
The zoning enforcement officer shall keep records of all
applications received, all Permits issued, all Stop Orders
issued and the action taken thereon.
SECTION 8 - Zoning Board of Appeals
8.1
Composition: The Board of Appeals shall consist of three (3)
persons not members of the Zoning Commission qualified and
appointed as provided in Special Act No. 306 of 1947, as
amended by Special Act No. 43 of 1971.

-24-
8.2
Powers and Duties:
The Board of Appeals shall have the power to:
(1) Adopt rules and procedures necessary to exercise its
authority.
(2) Hear and decide appeals where it is alleged that there
is an error in any order, requirement or decision made by the
official or officials charged with the enforcement of this
ordinance or any bylaw, ordinance or regulation adopted under
Special Act No. 306 of 1947 as amended by Special Act 43 of
1971 and/or Chapter 124, Title 8 of the General Statutes of
Connecticut Revised to 1991, as amended.
(3) Hear and decide all matters upon which it is required
to pass under the terms of this ordinance.
(4) Authorize upon application in specific cases
variances from the terms of these zoning regulations where
by reason of exceptional shape, size or topography of the lot
or other exceptional situation or condition of the building or
the land, practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship would
result to the owners of said property from a strict enforcement
of the zoning regulations. Before any variance is granted the
Board shall make a written finding in its minutes as part of the
record in the case: (a) that special circumstances, described

-25-
in detail, attach to the property which do not generally apply
to other property in the neighborhood and constitute the hard-
ship; (b) that relief can be granted without detriment to the
public welfare or impairment to the integrity of these
regulations.
8.3
Appeals to Board: Any person or persons aggrieved by any order,
requirement or decision of the official or officials charged
with the enforcement of the zoning regulations may appeal to
the Board of Appeals within fifteen (15) days from the date of
notice of such requirement or decision or the issuance of the
order.
The concurring vote of two members of the Board of Appeals
shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement or
decision of the official or officials charged with the
enforcement of the zoning regulations or to decide in
favor of the applicant any matter upon which it is required to
pass. Appeals in all other respects are governed by Section
8-7, 8-7a through 8-7d of the General Statutes of Connecticut
(Revised to 1991), as amended.

-26-
8.4
Procedure: All applications to the Board of Appeals under
8.3 above shall:
(1) State the name, address and telephone number of the
appellant;
(2) State why aggrieved in the case of an appeal;

SECTION 9 - Penalties
9.1
Any person who shall violate any provision of these Regulations
shall be subject to penalties in accordance with the General
Statutes of Connecticut.

-27-
SECTION 10 - Amendments
10.1
These Regulations may be amended by the Commission on its own
Initiative or when initiated by a petition. Any amendment may
be adopted only after due notice and public hearing as
prescribed by the General Statutes of Connecticut.
Section 11 - Validity
11.1
The invalidity of any Section, Paragraph or provision of
these Regulations shall not invalidate any other Section,
Paragraph or provision hereof.
Section 12 - Effective Date and Repeal
12.1
These Regulations, and any amendment or change hereto,
shall be in full force and effect from the date
established by the Commission in accordance with the
General Statutes of the State of Connecticut.
12.2
The "Zoning Regulations of the old Quarry Association, Inc.
Guilford, Connecticut" made effective by the Commission on
September 25, 1971, and all amendments thereto, are

-28-
repealed coincident with the effective date of these
Regulations. The repeal of the above Regulations and
all amendments thereto shall not affect or impair any
act done, offense committed, or right accruing, accrued,
or acquired or any liability, penalty, forfeiture, or
punishment incurred, prior to the time such repeal took
effect, but the same may be enjoyed, asserted, enforced,
prosecuted, or inflicted as fully and to the same extent
as if such repeal had not been effected.
